image.altText: Dust rising off a mine site with green hills in the foreground and background

items.synopsis: The discovery of heavy metals in the blood and rainwater of those living near a gold mine in New South Wales has sent shock waves through the community and sparked a major investigation.

title.children: Major investigation into gold mine after heavy metals found in residents' blood and rainwater

image.altText: Colombia's Linda Caceido dribbles the ball against a Jamaican defender, while a teammate looks on from behind.

items.synopsis: We will find out tonight whether the Matildas will face France or Morocco in the FIFA Women's World Cup quarterfinals, but first, surprise packets Colombia and Jamaica face off in Melbourne. Follow live.

title.children: Tonight we find out the Matildas' next opponent, but first it's Colombia vs Jamaica

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: They've got the breaktrhough! Catalina Usme finds the net. The cross came from Guzman deep on the left, and Usme's first touch was perfect, and her second was decisive. Beautifully taken goal, and that opens the game up.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 51' GOAAAAAAL COLOMBIA!

children.content: They've got the breaktrhough! Catalina Usme finds the net.
The cross came from Guzman deep on the left, and Usme's first touch was perfect, and her second was decisive.
Beautifully taken goal, and that opens the game up.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A very even game, plenty of niggle, lots of fouls. Whenboth teams decide to play it's great to watch. Two yellow cards for Jamaica already, you feel like something's gotta give in the second half. Here's Kate O'Halloran at the ground: The atmosphere is supercharged in Naarm/Melbourne for the knockout clash between Colombia and Jamaica, with neither side having scored at half time. The crowd is arguably the loudest of any of the World Cup fixtures hosted by this city, and that includes the match between the Matildas and Canada. Colombian fans have come out in force, or at least in voice. Aside from the odd chant of “Bunny” (for star striker ‘Bunny’ Shaw) from Jamaican fans, it’s all about ‘las Chicas Superpoderosas’ (The Powerpuff Girls) this Tuesday night. Colombia look the better side on the pitch, too. The Reggae Girlz, who are yet to concede a goal at the tournament to date, are hanging on admirably, but Colombia are setting up plenty of likely chances. The biggest roars have been reserved for their 18-year-old prodigy Linda Caicedo, one of the best emerging football talents in the world. She scored arguably the goal of the tournament against Germany in the group stages, and looks dangerous every time she goes near it. In fact, she’s causing so many headaches for the Jamaican defence that Drew Spence decided to tackle her to the ground, Aussie Rules style, earning her a yellow card just before half-time.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: HALF-TIME: Colombia 0 - 0 Jamaica

children.content: A very even game, plenty of niggle, lots of fouls. Whenboth teams decide to play it's great to watch. Two yellow cards for Jamaica already, you feel like something's gotta give in the second half.
Here's Kate O'Halloran at the ground:

The atmosphere is supercharged in Naarm/Melbourne for the knockout clash between Colombia and Jamaica, with neither side having scored at half time. The crowd is arguably the loudest of any of the World Cup fixtures hosted by this city, and that includes the match between the Matildas and Canada. Colombian fans have come out in force, or at least in voice. Aside from the odd chant of “Bunny” (for star striker ‘Bunny’ Shaw) from Jamaican fans, it’s all about ‘las Chicas Superpoderosas’ (The Powerpuff Girls) this Tuesday night.

Colombia look the better side on the pitch, too. The Reggae Girlz, who are yet to concede a goal at the tournament to date, are hanging on admirably, but Colombia are setting up plenty of likely chances. The biggest roars have been reserved for their 18-year-old prodigy Linda Caicedo, one of the best emerging football talents in the world. She scored arguably the goal of the tournament against Germany in the group stages, and looks dangerous every time she goes near it. In fact, she’s causing so many headaches for the Jamaican defence that Drew Spence decided to tackle her to the ground, Aussie Rules style, earning her a yellow card just before half-time.

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Colombia vs Jamaica is underway in Melbourne

image.altText: A side view of Roger Cook speaking at a press conference

items.synopsis: Just five weeks after being legislated, Roger Cook announces the WA government will be scrapping its Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Laws which he says caused 'division' and 'confusion' in the community.

title.children: WA to repeal controversial Indigenous cultural heritage laws weeks after they started

image.altText: A Transport Safety Bureau investigator places recovered MRH-90 Taipan voice and flight data recorder for transport in white box

items.synopsis: The MRH90 Taipan ditched into the ocean south of Hamilton Island 10 days ago during a training exercise.

title.children: Army helicopter's black box found as search for bodies of crew continues in Whitsundays

image.altText: Shane walks along carrying documents and wearing sunglasses.

items.synopsis: The ACT Bar Association said outgoing Director of Public Prosecutions Shane Drumgold currently held a restricted government practising certificate that allowed him to work as a barrister in the ACT, but only while employed in the top job or for that office.

title.children: ACT Bar Association has 'grave concerns' over findings of 'serious misconduct' against outgoing top prosecutor

image.altText: Hands put Australian coins into a wallet.

items.synopsis: Consumer confidence was down across all the mainland states, as analysis points to consumers still bracing for further rate rises.

title.children: Survey points to RBA cash rate over 5 per cent, as household sentiment plunges

image.altText: Scouts leave South Korea jamboree

items.synopsis: Teenagers from more than 100 countries, including over 900 Australians, have been evacuated from the World Scout Jamboree in South Korea in a logistical exercise of military-like precision.

title.children: One bus every 30 seconds: More than 37,000 teens evacuated from scout camp

image.altText: A timber frame surrounds a multi-storey building under construction

items.synopsis: Tasmania's first multi-storey building using timber is taking shape on the city skyline, as pressure grows to use alternatives to greenhouse-gas-intensive materials like steel.

title.children: 'The speed of construction has really surprised us': Multi-storey timber building takes shape

image.altText: A general view picture shows houses in the Israeli settlement of Maale Adumim, in the occupied West Bank.

items.synopsis: The federal government will begin to refer to Israel's settlements in the West Bank as "illegal settlements in the occupied territories", hardening its language on the Palestinian territories.

title.children: Government to harden stance against Israel's 'illegal settlements in occupied' West Bank

image.altText: two men close up

items.synopsis: One Nation's NSW leader Mark Latham files his defence to a defamation action brought by independent MP Alex Greenwich.

title.children: Latham claims alleged homophobic tweets 'enhanced' Greenwich's reputation

image.altText: Peter Dutton in the prime minister's courtyard

items.synopsis: The former home affairs minister knocked back a funding request recommended to help prevent crime in the Northern Territory town of Nhulunbuy, a federal audit committee reveals.

title.children: Peter Dutton criticised for rejecting crime prevention funding for NT town

image.altText: Two duffel bags are seen in a car boot, containing $100 bills packed in vacuum bags. 100K is written on one bag.

items.synopsis: Federal police found Christopher Alan Dean with almost $1 million in $100 bills in the boot of his car which he had parked at the beach.

title.children: 'Get Smart rather than James Bond': Man jailed after $1m cash found in car boot

image.altText: A middle-aged, bespectacled man, wearing a dark suit, walks in the sun.

items.synopsis: A remote court sitting has heard competing claims from FMG, traditional owners and the WA government amid a $500m dispute.

title.children: Federal Court judge questions value of native title laws that companies can ignore

image.altText: A composite image of Christopher Pyne and Joe Hockey

items.synopsis: In Australia there has long been disquiet about the revolving door between high political office and big business. Look at the defence industry, for example, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: A new generation of former MPs has turned to big business

image.altText: A North Melbourne VFL player holds up his left hand during a match against the Sydney Swans.

items.synopsis: North Melbourne midfielder Ben Cunnington joins a growing group of star retirements in the AFL. Check out the full list here.

title.children: 'My perspective in life was too great': Inspirational Kangaroos veteran calls time on AFL career

image.altText: Flowers in front of a Baptist church.

items.synopsis: As the community of Korumburra in Victoria's east waits for answers on the three deaths believed to be caused by a poisonous mushroom meal, parishioners at the local Baptist church say they "don't pass any judgement" about the circumstances of the tragedy.

title.children: 'We don't pass any judgement': Korumburra churchgoers pray for those involved in suspected mushroom triple fatality

image.altText: Flowers and police tape in scene of crime

items.synopsis: Tiffany Woodley is the victim of what police believe was a domestic dispute. WARNING: Indigenous readers are advised this story contains photos of someone who has died.

title.children: Mother killed in 'horrific' alleged domestic violence case identified, as homicide detectives investigate

items.synopsis: In the 1967 referendum on Indigenous rights, the NSW electorate of Cowper recorded one of the highest "no" votes. Now, Gumbaynggirr elders are reflecting on past lessons as they prepare for the second Indigenous referendum in their lifetime.

title.children: 'Thorn in everybody's side': Elders share thoughts on the Voice vote

image.altText: Bec Nicoll and Sarah Thomson crouch with their two dogs, on the ground of their wrecked house.

items.synopsis: Australians are facing a "broken" insurance system as the risk of bushfires, floods and cyclones increases with climate change, a new report out today says.

title.children: Bec and Sarah didn't want to repair a property that could just flood again. Turns out, their insurance claim wasn't that simple

image.altText: A group of soccer players wearing yellow and green hug each other while celebrating a win

items.synopsis: Having grappled with their heavyweight status, the Matildas defeated Denmark in the way only a serious World Cup contender should.

title.children: Are the Matildas coming of age after mature World Cup win over Denmark?

image.altText: A woman in a sari stands in front of shelves lined with black pots

items.synopsis: Gautam Adani won the tender to transform one of the world's largest slums into a thriving, modern metropolis. But those in Dharavi fear the development could push them out and turn it into a playground for the rich.

title.children: India's rich and famous live on the edge of a Mumbai slum. Now the land has become highly coveted

image.altText: A streak of light in the sky at night.

items.synopsis: Australia's space agency says an object that looked like a flaming meteor in the night sky over Victoria and Tasmania last night was most likely remnants of a Russian rocket returning to earth.

title.children: Flaming 'meteor' seen over south-eastern Australia likely Russian rocket parts, authorities say

image.altText: A woman in a red hat leaning on a rusty bar of a gate.

items.synopsis: Lawyers for Gina Rinehart claim a 1987 agreement shows Wright Prospecting relinquished any rights to Hancock Prospecting's Hope Downs project.

title.children: Court hears of 'fatal clauses' in Wright Prospecting's claim on Gina Rinehart's iron ore riches

image.altText: A view of a car damaged during heavy rain and strong winds brought by Typhoon Khanun in Chatan

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happened.

title.children: Flights cancelled as Typhoon Khanun lingers and K-pop star begins military service. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: Two police representatives outside court

items.synopsis: An officer who shot dead tradie Luke Gilbert in Airlie Beach last year has been questioned about his comments before the alleged confrontation, and whether he believed the tradie may have wanted to be shot.

title.children: Lawyer airs 'suicide by cop' theory in fatal Queensland police shooting as coroner questions officer's comments

image.altText: A woman with light brown hair holds a baby while a blonde woman and a man wearing a suit walk beside her

items.synopsis: The partner of an Adelaide man killed in a hit-and-run crash says the driver has blood on his hands that he will never be able to wash off.

title.children: 'Nick's blood stains your hands': Partner of hit-and-run victim confronts driver in court

image.altText: Luke Shuey celebrates with arms outstretched after kicking teh winning goal.

items.synopsis: The 2018 premiership player makes the announcement less than a week after teammate Shannon Hurn called time on his career.

title.children: Retiring West Coast Eagles great Luke Shuey reveals he was 'hoping for tap on the shoulder'

image.altText: A woman in a winter coat and glasses.

items.synopsis: A woman accused of murdering her elderly parents by giving them insulin has been granted bail in the Supreme Court.

title.children: Woman accused of killing parents granted bail by Supreme Court

image.altText: An Australian women's basketballer stands talking at a press conference.

items.synopsis: Ex-Opal Liz Cambage makes the shock claim she is trying to play for Nigeria, the basketball team she was accused of racially abusing before the Tokyo Olympics.

title.children: 'I would love to start fresh': Controversial ex-Opal Liz Cambage tips shock switch to Nigeria

image.altText: A man with grey hair and a grey beard is wearing a suit. He's leaning back in his chair and appears to be watching something.

items.synopsis: Controversial MP David O'Byrne confirms he wants to run as a Labor candidate at the next election — a decision that will be made by the national Labor executive rather than rank-and-file members.

title.children: Labor leader says she's made her position 'clear', as David O'Byrne seeks to return to the party

image.altText: A man gestures to a woman.

items.synopsis: A man who had four different relationships with women between 2009 and 2020, was financially controlling, volatile, and demanded sex, a Supreme Court jury hears.

title.children: Man on trial accused of rape, domestic violence charges involving four women

image.altText: Photo of chillis

items.synopsis: Chilli might turn up the heat on the food you eat but turn down the risk of dementia, researchers at one Queensland university say.

title.children: Spicy chilli to be probed for dementia-preventing capabilities

image.altText: three off shaped carrots

items.synopsis: Australia's largest food relief charity wants the federal government to change its tax arrangements to make donating unwanted produce less costly for businesses.

title.children: Could tax perks for donating 'ugly' or excess produce help solve Australia's food waste woes?

image.altText: A koala sitting on the sand on a beach.

items.synopsis: Customers at a beach cafe in northern NSW were surprised to see a koala strolling along the sand in the winter sun. But its adventure has sparked concerns about habitat loss.

title.children: Rare sight of koala visiting beach delights onlookers, but wildlife carers raise concerns

image.altText: People silhouetted against a white and blue KPMG logo.

items.synopsis: Newly compiled data reveals Defence has spent nearly $4 billion on large consulting firms over the past decade, more than all other Australian government departments combined.

title.children: 'Something's rotten': New analysis reveals $4 billion Defence department spend on consultancy firms
